questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-day history of increasing confusion and lethargy. He reports decreased urine output and abdominal pain for the past month. Two months ago, he was hospitalized for pyelonephritis and treated with ceftriaxone. He has a history of chronic hepatitis C. He does not take any medications. He appears pale and irritable. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person but not to time or place. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. The abdomen is distended with a positive fluid wave. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4300/mm3



Platelet count
89,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
19 sec


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
71 mg/dL


 Glucose
99 mg/dL


 Creatinine

3.5 mg/dL


 ALT
137 U/L


 AST
154 U/L


Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. FENa is < 1%. Ultrasound of the kidneys is unremarkable. Intravenous fluids are administered for 36 hours but do not improve urine output. Which of the following is the most likely cause of kidney dysfunction in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the renal interstitium is seen in tubulointerstitial diseases, including allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), which is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs, such as penicillins, cephalosporins, NSAIDs, and allopurinol. AIN typically manifests within days or weeks after initiating treatment with flank pain, hematuria, and fever, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation. Urinalysis usually shows hematuria, pyuria, and eosinophiluria. Moreover, this patient's ceftriaxone use was two months ago, so it is unlikely to cause interstitial inflammation now.

B) INCORRECT:

Immune-mediated mesangial proliferation is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), which is commonly associated with HCV infection. It typically results in nephrotic syndrome but can also manifest with nephritic syndrome, so varying degrees of proteinuria, hematuria, edema, and hypertension would be expected. Elevated creatinine levels and reduced urine output, as seen in this patient, can occur. However, urinalysis would show heavy proteinuria (> 3.5 g/24h) and fatty casts with or without hematuria as well, while this patient's urinalysis is unremarkable.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal vein thrombosis is a complication of hypercoagulable state and typically manifests with flank pain and hematuria, as well as anuria and elevated creatinine levels if bilateral thrombosis occurs. Patients with cirrhosis, as in this case, typically have impaired production of clotting factors and fibrinolytic factors, thrombocytopenia and/or platelet dysfunction, as well as altered blood flow, which puts them at risk of both bleeding and thrombosis, respectively. This patient has a low platelet count and a prolonged prothrombin time, which, in conjunction with the unremarkable renal ultrasound, makes this an unlikely diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient with decompensated liver cirrhosis most likely has hepatorenal syndrome. As portal hypertension worsens in patients with decompensated cirrhosis, vasodilatory mediators are produced, leading to vasodilation of the splanchnic circulation. The altered hemodynamics result in renal hypoperfusion, which in turn causes a decrease in GFR. Patients typically present with gradual loss of kidney function, as seen in this patient who developed oliguria over a period of 1 month, an unremarkable urine sediment, and fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) < 1% and BUN/Cr ratio > 20. Treatment of this condition includes administration of albumin, octreotide, and midodrine. A liver transplant is the only curative option in advanced liver disease.

No improvement of renal function after fluid therapy is also consistent with this diagnosis and helps differentiate from prerenal causes of acute kidney injury (AKI), such as hypotension or hypovolemia. In prerenal AKI, the first-line treatment is IV fluid administration, which usually results in quick recovery in kidney function.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal tubular injury can result in acute tubular necrosis (ATN), which can develop in patients with cirrhosis secondary to exposure to a nephrotoxin (e.g., aminoglycosides, contrast agent) or a period of ischemia (e.g., sepsis or bleeding with a decrease in blood pressure). ATN typically manifests with signs of AKI, so oliguria and elevated creatinine and BUN levels are consistent with this diagnosis. However, these findings generally develop much more rapidly than in this patient, and urinalysis would show granular epithelial cell casts and renal tubular epithelial cells. Lastly, as the most common form of intrinsic AKI, ATN can be distinguished from prerenal AKI and this patient's condition using the fractional excretion of sodium (FENa). Intrinsic AKI is associated with FENa > 1% because the damaged tubules are unable to reabsorb sodium sufficiently.

F) INCORRECT:

Renal microvascular thrombi can be seen in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), which is an important differential to consider in patients with altered mental status, signs of acute kidney injury, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Although TTP can occur in association with systemic diseases and infections, an association with hepatitis C has not been established. The clinical presentation is generally much more abrupt and severe than in this patient and is characterized by a pentad of findings: neurological symptoms (e.g., altered mental state, seizure, coma), fever, proteinuria, hematuria, renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia with bleeding manifestations (petechiae, bleeding gums, occult GI bleeding).
questions.hint: Ascites, jaundice, and laboratory results showing impaired liver function, prolonged prothrombin time, and hematologic abnormalities in a patient with untreated hepatitis C infection is highly suggestive of decompensated liver cirrhosis. Thrombocytopenia and leukopenia in patients with cirrhosis are typically due to hypersplenism from portal hypertension, while the cause of anemia is often multifactorial (e.g., hypersplenism, blood loss, vitamin B12 deficiency, folate deficiency).

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis secondary to hepatitis C virus infection is admitted to the intensive care unit with encephalopathy and acute kidney injury. His outpatient medications include lactulose, furosemide, and spironolactone.
On examination, he is afebrile, his blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 80 beats per minute. He has spider angiomas on his chest and palmar erythema. No rash is present. His abdomen is distended, with a visible fluid wave. He is oriented to person and place but does not know the year. Asterixis is present. The rest of the neurologic examination is unremarkable.

The diuretics are discontinued, and intravenous albumin is administered. Diagnostic paracentesis reveals a fluid leukocyte count of 130 per mm3 . The fluid albumin level is 0.2 g/dL.
Two days later, the serum creatinine level is 4.0 mg/dL, and the patient’s urine output is declining. The kidneys appear normal on renal ultrasonography, without evidence of hydronephrosis.
Additional laboratory testing shows a urine sodium level of < 10 mEq/liter. The urine sediment does not contain red or white cells or granular casts. There is no evidence of proteinuria.
Which one of the following approaches is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Schedule placement of a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt
Initiate treatment with a vasoconstrictor (terlipressin or norepinephrine)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

TIPS has been evaluated as initial therapy in hepatorenal syndrome in some small uncontrolled studies, but it is still considered investigational. This technique also requires intravenous contrast, which can contribute to kidney injury.

B) CORRECT:

Kidney failure in patients with cirrhosis can result from hypovolemia, parenchymal kidney disease, drugs, or hepatorenal syndrome (as in this patient). All of the following criteria must be met to make a diagnosis of hepatorenal syndrome:

• Cirrhosis with ascites
• Diagnosis of acute kidney injury (an increase in serum creatinine of ≥ 0.3 mg/dL from baseline within 48 hours or ≥ 50% from baseline within 7 days)
• No response after 2 consecutive days of diuretic withdrawal and plasma volume expansion with albumin infusions (1 g/kg of body weight daily)
• Absence of shock
• No current or recent use of nephrotoxic drugs (nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, aminoglycosides, or iodinated contrast media)
• No signs of structural kidney injury, as indicated by urine protein excretion > 500 mg daily, urine red cell excretion > 50 red cells per high-power field, or abnormal renal ultrasound

Hepatorenal syndrome is thought to result from splanchnic arterial vasodilation, leading to reduced effective arterial blood volume and activation of sodium-retaining vasoconstrictor systems. The prognosis is poor. Treatment focuses on daily infusions of albumin for volume expansion and the use of vasoconstrictors to reverse splanchnic vasodilation.

The combination of albumin and a vasoconstrictor — either terlipressin or norepinephrine — has been shown to improve kidney function in the setting of hepatorenal syndrome, with an average response rate of 50%. When used in conjunction with vasoconstrictors, albumin is infused at a dose of 1 g/kg of body weight on day one of therapy followed by 40 to 50 g daily, continued for the duration of therapy. Midodrine and octreotide can be used together in place of terlipressin or norepinephrine, but current evidence suggests that this approach is generally less effective; it is an alternative for patients who are not in the intensive care unit and therefore cannot receive norepinephrine.

If a patient does not respond to 4 days of maximally tolerated doses of a vasoconstrictor (i.e., their creatinine level remains at or above their pretreatment level), the clinician may reasonably discontinue therapy for futility. Choosing a next step in such patients is controversial, but options may include liver (or combined liver-kidney) transplant, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunts (TIPS), or hemodialysis.

Key learning point: The primary therapy for hepatorenal syndrome consists of albumin in combination with a vasoconstrictor such as terlipressin or norepinephrine.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis is typically reserved for patients with hepatorenal syndrome who have not responded to vasoconstrictor therapy and are awaiting liver transplantation. Hemodialysis is used to manage electrolyte abnormalities and uremic symptoms. There is no acute indication for dialysis in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as dexamethasone, have no role in managing hepatorenal syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Dopamine is ineffective for treating hepatorenal syndrome, despite its purported selective renal-vasodilating effects.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic low back pain, and chronic hepatitis C virus infection with decompensated cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with weakness, low-grade fevers, and fatigue for the past week. He reports no abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, melena, or hematochezia but does note reduced urine output.
His current medications are spironolactone 100 mg once daily, furosemide 40 mg once daily, insulin degludec 12 units daily, and acetaminophen occasionally for back pain. He reports no use of opioids or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.
On physical examination, he appears well and is in no acute distress. His temperature is 37.4°C, his heart rate is 94 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 90/53 mm Hg, his respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 96% while he breathes ambient air. One week ago, the patient’s blood urea nitrogen level was 12 mg/dL, and his creatinine concentration was 1.2 mg/dL.
Urinalysis with sediment is negative for red cells, white cells, protein, leukocyte esterase, nitrites, and casts. The urine sodium level is 5 mEq/liter (reference range varies with intake).
The patient is treated with one liter of normal saline. A diagnostic paracentesis is performed, and 50 mL of clear, straw-colored fluid is removed. Analysis of the ascites fluid reveals a neutrophil count of 700 per mm3 .
The patient is started on intravenous ceftriaxone and albumin for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis and is admitted to the hospital, where these medications are continued. His home oral diuretics are held, and he is given additional intravenous albumin on the second hospital day. After 48 hours, his renal function has not improved.
In addition to continuing albumin, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for managing this patient’s acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal replacement therapy, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunts, and liver transplantation should be considered for patients who do not respond to medical therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal biopsy is not indicated in this case, as the patient’s clinical presentation is typical for hepatorenal syndrome. Renal biopsy could be considered if the patient had an active urine sediment or significant proteinuria.

C) CORRECT:

This patient likely has hepatorenal syndrome (HRS). HRS occurs in the setting of cirrhosis and portal hypertension when an increase in vasodilatory factors leads to splanchnic vasodilation and a decrease in systemic vascular resistance. Splanchnic diversion of blood volume results in effective circulating volume depletion, which in turn leads to renal vasoconstriction and hypoperfusion.

HRS can be difficult to distinguish from diuretic-induced prerenal azotemia because laboratory results for the two conditions are similar; therefore, volume repletion should be given in the form of intravenous albumin (1 g/kg of body weight, up to 100 g per day) for at least 2 days. If the albumin does not correct the renal dysfunction, HRS is the likely diagnosis.

All of the following criteria must be met to make a diagnosis of HRS:

• Cirrhosis with ascites
• Diagnosis of acute kidney injury (an increase in serum creatinine of ≥0.3 mg/dL from baseline within 48 hours or ≥50% from baseline within 7 days)
• No response after 2 consecutive days of diuretic withdrawal and plasma volume expansion with albumin infusions (1g/kg of body weight per day)
• Absence of shock
• No current or recent use of nephrotoxic drugs (nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, aminoglycosides, or iodinated contrast media)
• No signs of structural kidney injury, as indicated by urine protein excretion >500 mg daily, urine red cell excretion >50 red cells per high-power field, or abnormal renal ultrasound

Treatment of HRS includes management of any underlying precipitants as well as therapy directed at the HRS itself. Precipitants of HRS include spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (as in this case), other infections, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is treated with antibiotics and intravenous albumin.

Initial medical treatment of HRS depends on the availability of medications. All patients should receive intravenous albumin and a vasoconstrictor. The first-line options for a vasoconstrictor are terlipressin and norepinephrine; the latter of which must typically be administered in an intensive care setting. An alternative treatment for patients who are not critically ill, and therefore not in an intensive care unit, is the combination of octreotide and midodrine. However, current evidence suggests that this combination is less effective than terlipressin or norepinephrine.

Key learning point: Initial medical therapy for hepatorenal syndrome in non-critically ill patients consists of albumin combined with a vasoconstrictor. Terlipressin and norepinephrine are considered first-line options; if neither is available, the combination of midodrine and octreotide can be used.

D) INCORRECT:

Diuretic treatment with intravenous furosemide is not indicated in this patient with evidence of intravascular volume depletion and a relatively low blood pressure; as noted above, cessation of diuretics is an important component of the diagnosis and management of hepatorenal syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Paracentesis can improve renal blood flow in cases of tense ascites, but large-volume paracentesis should be avoided in patients with kidney injury and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, because this approach can cause substantial fluid shifts and result in further declines in kidney function.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with cirrhosis and ascites is transferred from a community hospital for worsening acute kidney injury. At the community hospital, his serum creatinine increased from 1.2 mg/dL to 2.1 mg/dL over the past 5 days despite diuretic withdrawal and two consecutive days of albumin infusion. He denies recent nephrotoxic drug use and has no fever or hemodynamic instability. Large-volume paracentesis was performed with ascitic fluid neutrophil count of 180 cells/μL. Blood, urine, and ascitic fluid cultures were negative. Vital signs are BP, 105/65; P, 88; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination shows an alert and oriented patient with nontense ascites. Abdominal ultrasound shows no portal vein thrombosis or biliary obstruction. Urinalysis shows no proteinuria or hematuria. The fractional excretion of sodium is 0.1%. Laboratory studies show creatinine 2.2 mg/dL, BUN 48 mg/dL, Na 125 mEq/L, K 4.7 mEq/L, CO2 20 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While renal replacement therapy may be considered as a bridging therapy for patients awaiting liver transplantation, this patient does not currently have an indication for urgent dialysis. Furthermore, renal replacement therapy is associated with significant adverse effects (e.g., hypotension, bleeding, and infection), does not improve mortality, and is not the primary treatment for hepatorenal syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Although combination therapy with midodrine and octreotide is an alternative treatment option for hepatorenal syndrome-acute kidney injury, it is not the preferred first-line therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient meets the diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome-acute kidney injury (HRS-AKI): cirrhosis with ascites, acute kidney injury with no improvement after diuretic withdrawal and two consecutive days of albumin, absence of shock or nephrotoxic agents, and no structural kidney disease. The preferred treatment for HRS-AKI involves a vasoconstrictor, such as terlipressin, combined with albumin infusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Large-volume paracentesis is used to treat tense ascites, but this patient currently has nontense ascites, making an alternative step in management more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Albumin infusion is used in the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome-acute kidney injury (HRS-AKI). However, the patient has already received two consecutive days of albumin without improvement in kidney function and requires an alternative step in management at this time.
